hero.badge: The Growth Hacking Process: A Step-by-Step Guide
hero.title: Growth Hacking Is a Process, Not a Trick
hero.subtitle: Growth hacking is not a magical solution or a quick fix. It is a disciplined, repeatable process of experimentation, measurement, and refinement.
hero.quote: Fall in love with the process, and the results will come - Eric Thomas

intro.title: Growth marketing is a system
intro.p1: There is no single trick. The companies that scale do it by running a strict, data-driven process. Discovering "silver bullets" is the result of hard work, not random ideas.
intro.p2: Do you follow a structured approach for researching, prioritizing, designing, testing, and analyzing growth experiments? If not, your experiments are unlikely to produce consistent paying customers.
intro.p3: A magic growth hack that works for everyone does not exist. Beyond the buzz, growth hacking is a step-by-step process.
intro.p4: Scraping, automation, virality loops, and other "hacky" tactics can be powerful, but without a disciplined system they rarely create sustainable growth.
intro.quickLook: A quick look into the process

overview: Develop playbooks to iterate and scale

step1.title: Find Product-Market Fit
step1.p1: A fast growth process is useless without product-market fit. If users would not miss your product, growth will not save you. Your priority is building the right product for the right market.
step1.noteBody: Embrace a lean approach: identify your potential customers, understand their needs, and build a product that turns them into early advocates. It takes time and iteration, but scaling a weak product wastes even more time.
step1.signalsTitle: How do you know you reached PMF?

signals.title: Sean Ellis "Very Disappointed" method
points: Survey active users with: "How would you feel if you could no longer use our product tomorrow?"
Options: extremely upset, somewhat upset, not upset at all, or I no longer use this.
If 40%+ answer "very disappointed", you have a strong PMF signal.

signals.title: Brian Balfour Trifecta
points: High retention and low churn for the category.
Meaningful, frequent product usage that matches the core value.

step1.overlapBody: There is overlap between the Problem-Solution Fit phase and PMF. At this stage, growth hacking can be used to explore opportunities in data and behavior patterns. Use frameworks like the Bullseye Template from Traction to focus on the most promising channels, but never use growth tactics to mask a product without real pull.
step1.timingBody: Growth processes work best when the company is past the early validation phase and ready to scale. The right strategy at the right time turns a good product into a fast-growing business.

step2.title: Five prerequisites before you scale
step2.p1: Once you hit PMF, the growth process still needs a foundation. Align the team on these prerequisites before rapid experimentation.
step2.p2: Growth is a team sport. Everyone involved in the process needs to understand the system. A clear foundation ensures experiments are focused and measurable.

cards.title: Business Model Canvas
cards.desc: A one-page visual model of your value proposition, customers, channels, operations, and economics. It aligns teams and speeds onboarding.

cards.title: Value Proposition Canvas
cards.desc: Clarifies how your product solves real customer pains and creates gains. It should reflect actual customer behavior, not idealized assumptions.

cards.title: Personas
cards.desc: Define 2 to 3 key personas deeply: goals, behaviors, pain points, alternatives, and decision criteria. Validate them with real feedback.

cards.title: Pirate Funnel (AAARRR)
cards.desc: Map the user journey (Awareness, Acquisition, Activation, Retention, Referral, Revenue) and define the key actions and metrics at each stage.

cards.title: OMTM + North Star
cards.desc: Pick one metric that matters right now (OMTM). It changes over time, but it should always move you toward the North Star metric.

personaPoints: Focus on the 2 to 3 most important personas first.
Define deeper traits: goals, behaviors, day-in-the-life, and current alternatives.
Validate and refine personas through real tests and feedback.
step2.omtmBody: Your OMTM is a short-term focus that changes as you hit milestones. The North Star metric is the long-term direction. For example, a team might focus on trial conversion this month while the North Star is total hours delivered or recurring revenue.

step3.title: Implement Rapid Experimentation (G.R.O.W.S)
step3.p1: The growth loop makes experimentation predictable, fast, and measurable. It is how winning teams find the few experiments that unlock exponential growth.
step3.p2: It does not matter if you follow the Sean Ellis or Growth Tribe flavor of G.R.O.W.S. The structure is what creates speed and learning. If you want a visual walkthrough, Growth Tribe's David Arnoux has a clear step-by-step explanation of the loop.

grows.title: Gather Ideas
grows.desc: Collect hypotheses that could improve your OMTM. Use market research, qualitative insights, and quantitative data to feed a structured idea backlog.
bullets: Observe your market: best practices, trends, articles, and competitor patterns.
Quantitative data shows what happens; qualitative data explains why it happens.
Idea format: concept title, 5Ws + H, theory, success metric, and minimum benchmark.
Use a shared system to capture ideas, rank them, and track outcomes.

grows.title: Rank Ideas
grows.desc: Prioritize with a scoring model (ICE, BRASS, PIES). Focus on momentum: mix high-impact bets with low-effort wins.
bullets: Ask the team to nominate a few top ideas before the sprint meeting.
Decide and ship the best-scoring experiments each cycle.
Include low-hanging fruit to keep velocity high.

grows.title: Outline Experiments
grows.desc: Keep it fast and simple. Design experiments that can ship quickly and validate potential before heavy investment.
bullets: Define roles: Growth Lead, Developer, Designer, Analyst.
Use agile rituals to keep velocity high.
Done is better than perfect when the goal is speed and learning.

grows.title: Work the Plan
grows.desc: Execute. Do the 20% of work that yields 80% of results. If the test shows promise, double down; if not, move on.
bullets: Optimize for speed and learning, not perfection.
Agile Scrum principles help the team ship fast and stay aligned.

grows.title: Study the Data
grows.desc: Analyze carefully and categorize outcomes: inconclusive, failed (learned), failed (tweak), success (explore), success (scale).
bullets: Expect failures; they are part of the path to a breakthrough.
Segment results by device, audience, geography, or product cohort.
Document learnings so the next tests are smarter.

analysisPoints: The experiment ends (usually 1 to 3 weeks to reduce seasonality).
The growth lead reviews results using a consistent evaluation template.
Classify outcomes: inconclusive, failure (no tweak), failure (tweak), success (explore), success (scale).
abPrereqs: You need enough volume. A good rule of thumb is 1,000 conversions on the target action.
Early stage teams should run bigger changes instead of tiny tweaks.
Pick a statistical approach that matches your speed, risk tolerance, and team communication.

abNotes.title: Frequentist approach
bullets: Lower risk of false positives, but requires higher significance (95%+).
Slower velocity because you need more data before calling a winner.
Harder to communicate to non-technical teams.

abNotes.title: Bayesian approach
bullets: Higher velocity with probability thresholds (ex: 80% = winner).
Better for fast-moving teams where speed matters.
Easier to communicate: "Variant B has an 84% chance to win."

step4.title: Develop playbooks to iterate and scale
step4.p1: Store every experiment with its hypothesis, setup, results, and learnings. A living knowledge base prevents repeated failures and accelerates onboarding for new team members.
step4.p2: Keep communication open. Many top teams share weekly updates or maintain a dedicated channel for experiment results and learnings. This keeps momentum high and aligns stakeholders.

home.capabilitiesSubtitle: Strategy, experimentation, and execution built around sustainable growth. Everything ties back to your North Star metric.
home.playbooksDesc: Every experiment is documented and turned into playbooks for faster onboarding, clearer learning, and smarter iteration.
